Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy in Reducing Perioperative Stress and ICU Stay in Neurosurgical Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: Eighty adult patients scheduled for elective brain surgery were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at Shohadaye Tajrish Hospital, Tehran, Iran, from 2020 to 2022. Eighty adult patients scheduled for elective brain surgery

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received 15 CBT sessions focused on stress management and cognitive restructuring.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the effectiveness of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) in reducing perceived stress and ICU stay in neurosurgical patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Stress levels were assessed using Cohen’s Perceived Stress Scale pre- and post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using simple randomisation, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to patients or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 40 patients were randomised to each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: all were included in the analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Postoperative perceived stress scores were significantly lower in the CBT group (mean difference = 17.09, 95% CI 15.12 to 19.06; p<0.001).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
